column1: University Park is a city in Dallas County

column1: University Park began as a cluster of homes surrounding the fledgling Southern Methodist University
column2: which was founded in the then-rural Dallas County in 1915. The university supplied these homes with utility service until 1924
column3: when the growing population could no longer be supported by the school's utilities. In response
column4: the area's homeowners first sought annexation into the town of Highland Park
column5: but were refused due to the high cost that would have been required to provide the necessary utility and safety services. Shortly thereafter
column6: Dallas also refused a request for annexation on similar grounds.

column1: Community leaders organized to incorporate as a separate individual city. According to state law
column2: incorporation required that area residents hold an election on the issue before the new city could be officially formed and recognized. On April 24
column4: voters approved the measure by a 5:1 margin. Operating under the commission form of government
column5: the city began the work of shaping the new government and addressing the pressing need to establish basic municipal services. To provide for the financial needs of the city
column6: another election was held soon thereafter to authorize the issuance of municipal bonds. Passing by a near unanimous margin
column8: 000 bond issue funded the installation of a new water supply system
column10: and the construction of a new city hall and fire station. When first incorporated

column1: As a result of efforts to build and improve the city
column2: University Park grew to a population of over 20
column3: 000 residents by 1945 and had become one of the most prestigious locations in the area. In fact
column4: the community's attractiveness and tax value had risen to such an extent that the city of Dallas now wanted to annex University Park into its boundaries. At the time of the election
column5: even the Board of Commissioners favored the election. In the largest voter turnout to that date and still one of the largest in city history
column6: the annexation was denied by a 53% to 47% margin.

column1: In 1946 an election to adopt a Home Rule Charter was held
column2: but the measure failed and the city continued to operate as a General Law city. In 1989 voters approved a Home Rule Charter which officially adopted a council-manager form of government and expanded the three member board of Commissioners into a five-member city council.
the population and area of University Park has stabilized at 24
column4: 350 acres (4.7 square miles). The city is now surrounded by Dallas on three sides and the town of Highland Park to the south.

column1: Originally University Park was a middle class community. Highland Park residents spearheaded the creation of the Highland Park Independent School District and asked the neighbors to the north to become a part of the district; taxes were lower since the district included University Park's population. HPISD had no racial diversity in the 1950s and 1960s
column2: when other Dallas-area school districts dealt with racial integration and white flight. The federal court orders to integrate had no effect in HPISD since it did not receive federal money. As a result
column3: values of HPISD-zoned properties in University Park rose dramatically and the demographic makeup became wealthier
column4: with smaller houses being replaced by larger ones circa the 1970s.

column1: University Park is served by the Highland Park Independent School District (HPISD). As such
column2: it is served by the HPISD's McCulloch Intermediate School and Highland Park Middle School (which share a campus located partially in Highland Park and partially in University Park)
column3: and Highland Park High School located in University Park. There are two HPISD elementary schools located in University Park (Hyer and University Park)
column4: two HPISD elementary schools located in neighboring Highland Park (Armstrong and Bradfield) and one elementary school located in the city of Dallas (Michael M. Boone Elementary). All five elementary schools serve sections of the UP city limits.A small portion of University Park west of North Central Expressway is in the Dallas Independent School District.
